awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  How do shifts from migratory to sedentary behavior alter host-parasite dynamics?
awd_abstract_narration:
Every year, billions of animals migrate long distances. If animals with parasites are less likely to reach their destinations, then migration may allow populations to escape habitats where parasites build up over time. Understanding how animal migration affects the spread of disease is important to predicting disease risk, including to humans. This study focuses on monarch butterflies as a model system and explores the impacts of parasites on butterfly populations that migrate and populations that have recently lost their migratory habits. This study will also examine how non-migrating populations may influence the risk of having parasites by the migrating forms in areas where they come together. Field and experimental studies will also examine how these microscopic parasites influence how long butterflies live and their flight ability.  Through the high visibility and public appeal of monarchs, this project will support the participation of citizen scientists on a continental scale. The investigators will also mentor and train undergraduate and graduate students and will develop web and classroom based educational materials on host-parasite relationships and animal migration. This work will provide additional opportunities for middle school students and support k-12 activities. Finally, this work will inform efforts to conserve monarch butterflies and our understanding of how migration may influence the importance of parasites across many systems.  

Using a monarch butterflies and protozoan parasite system, the goal of this study is to examine how migratory and sedentary behaviors influence transmission risk and severity of infection. Research activities will integrate (i) an analysis of continent-wide citizen science databases to monitor monarch butterfly abundance and infection; (ii) field and experimental studies to test how monarch migratory behavior depends on non-native milkweeds and infection status, and to quantify parasite transmission rates; (iii) molecular genomics to ask whether genetic changes in sedentary populations might reinforce the loss of migratory behavior; and (iv) mathematical modeling to track how host and parasite populations respond to migratory vs. sedentary strategies. Information on the mixing of non-migrants and migrants, inferred from stable isotope analyses of field-collected monarchs, will inform mathematical models of interacting sedentary and migratory populations, to explore the consequences for disease spread and the persistence of migratory populations. The project will develop theory for how overlapping migration strategies alter, and are themselves affected by, parasite infection, and will shed light on the evolution of migration by characterizing genetic changes that accompany the recent formation of sedentary populations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes 

Award Title: Collaborative Research: How do shifts from migratory to sedentary behavior alter host-parasite dynamics?

PI: Caroline Taylor

Federal Award ID: 1208831

We have been studying one of the world?s great animal migrations, that of the eastern North American population of monarch butterflies (Danaus plexippus). Every spring, monarch butterflies leave their wintering grounds in Mexico and travel north to produce young, each generation moves further north until the generation that emerges in the early fall migrates south, up to 3000 miles, to spend their winter in the Mexican oyamel fir forests used by their great -great grandparents in the previous year. How this feat is achieved remains one of the great mysteries in the natural world and monarchs are a source of inspiration and curiosity for scientists and the public. 

To understand how a system works, we can study how it is changed by novel conditions. Migratory populations and patterns are continually altered by urbanization, climate change, habitat change, predation, and disease. Disease and migration are strongly linked and there are several ecological and evolutionary theories that lead us to expect lower prevalence of disease in migratory compared to resident populations.

In recent decades, monarchs seem to be ?dropping out? of migration and have formed novel, resident (permanent) and sedentary (impermanent) populations along the northern Gulf Coast. Studies prior to our project had shown that the prevalence of Ophryocystis elektroscirrha (OE), a protozoan disease specific to monarchs, was higher in a resident population in South Florida than in the migratory population. 

Our 2.5-year monitoring of monarchs in the urban setting of New Orleans revealed that monarchs were breeding year-round there, using a non-native species of milkweed, Asclepias curassavica, called tropical milkweed commonly planted in gardens. Our monitoring also showed that, following a series of freeze events in January 2018, monarchs disappeared for several weeks, returning in March/April apparently from the Mexican winter population. After their return, prevalence of OE increased from about 10% of monarchs infected in April to 100% by July then dropped off again in the Fall, which we attribute to dilution from mostly uninfected migratory monarchs arriving from the north and built back up to almost 100% as the winter breeding progressed. We constructed an agent-based model to replicate these dynamics and explore what would happen under different climate regimes. Essentially, we found that high prevalence of OE by the end of the year was an inevitable outcome of winter breeding in any climate but that winter freezes would reduce the prevalence earlier in the year when monarchs in the Gulf region might interact with migrants. 

An analysis of data from the citizen science program, Project Monarch Health, revealed a latitudinal pattern of OE prevalence, with extremely high (~83% butterflies infected) in South Florida, declining as you move northward. The analysis also showed seasonal patterns of OE in monarchs in the Western Gulf region, (matching our observations from the New Orleans monitoring), but little to no seasonal oscillations in the North Florida region, despite a similar climate. We believe the seasonal patterns in the Western gulf region are attributable to winter freezes followed by re-colonization in spring from the wintering migratory population and we attribute the lack of seasonal patterns in North Florida to its proximity and continual recolonization from to the permanent resident, and highly infected, population in South Florida. 

We note that there is nothing intrinsically ?bad? about tropical milkweed as a host plant for monarchs. It is not considered invasive, and our experiments showed that monarchs grow faster, bigger, and apparently healthier on tropical milkweed compared to other locally native species, especially Asclepias incarnata, known as swamp milkweed.  We conducted a systematic review of literature that measured the ability of monarch caterpillars to survive on different host plants and a metanalysis of papers that measured the concentrations of a class of toxic compounds called cardenolides in different species. We started with a list of 127 plant species that have been claimed or tested to be host plants. We found that 34 of these are high performance plants (including tropical milkweed), 42 were low performance (monarchs could survival on them but mortality rates were high) , 33 were non hosts, and the claims that the remaining 18 are host plants for monarchs are unsubstantiated. We also found higher concentration of cardenolides, in high than low performance plants.

We do not know for sure how often or when these sedentary populations interact with the migrants, but we think that the OE levels in sedentary populations are likely driving an increase in OE and therefore pose a risk to the migratory population.  For gardeners in the Gulf Coast region, we recommend either planting native species of milkweed, that would naturally senesce in the fall or cutting back tropical milkweed to reduce winter-breeding and infection levels.
